posts.title: Why MacPaint's Original Canvas was 416 Pixels Wide
posts.markdown:
Back in the mid 80's after we had [finished writing](/all-i-really-need-to-know-i-learned-from-a-128k-mac/) [GATO for the Macintosh](http://www.bytecellar.com/2006/03/15/of_ajax_gato_an/), I took some time to explore the underbelly of the Mac. One of these times I discovered that a single M68k operation determined the way MacPaint was visually designed. 

![Programmer's Switch circa 1984](http://www.jeffreythompson.org/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/MacProgrammersSwitchFrom1984Macintosh128kM0001-web.png)<sub>Image courtesy of [Jeff Thompson's blog](http://www.jeffreythompson.org/blog/2012/08/22/programmers-switch/)</sub>

This was the time of the Mac 128k and the "Fat Mac", aka, the 512k Mac. Debugging the Mac meant hitting the [Programmer's Switch](http://www.jeffreythompson.org/blog/2012/08/22/programmers-switch/) that all of us developers had installed. It would in turn open up a [MacsBug](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacsBug) session.


On this particular day I was curious how MacPaint was so fast at re-rendering the canvas drawing area. You could especially see this during an undo operation. I knew that it was using an off-screen buffer and had to bitblit it back to the screen. I also knew that this was all done in software. So how to find out? I decided to do lots of undos while quickly hitting the interrupt switch.

I noticed that I landed on a certain piece of code in almost every situation. Here is this [same piece of code](http://www.computerhistory.org/atchm/macpaint-and-quickdraw-source-code/) courtesy of the Computer History Museum's addition of the MacPaint and the QuickDraw source code to its archives. This is nice because we have [Bill Atkinson](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Atkinson)'s comments, which I didn't have back in the day. 

![MacPaint source code for BufToScrn](http://billwscott.com/files/macpaint-buf-to-scrn-src.png)

The key to this really fast render operation was the use of the Motorola 68k's MOVEM command. MOVEM stands for Move Multiple. It can take a range of registers and move bits from an address into the M68k registers or do the reverse.

Here is how this algorithm worked:

![MacPaint BufToScrn Illustrated](http://billwscott.com/files/macpaint-buf-to-scrn-explained.png)

In this example there are a few "on" bits at the top of the lady's hair. You can see that the MOVEM.L (A0),D0-D7/A2-A6 moves long words (32 bits) from the pointer at A0 (which is the memory location of the portion of the screen buffer being copied). Notice the registers get populated with the bits from the buffer. Registers D4-D7 have lots of 1's which represent a row of her black hair.

The next MOVEM.L D0-D7/A2-A6,(A1) moves the contents of the registers to the screen. A1 points to the start of the screen memory. The (A1) in parenthesis in M68k assembler denotes indirect addressing (btw, I have always felt that M68k assembler was a joy to work with).

Now this is all fine and dandy. But the real epiphany to me was when I discovered this algorithm was the reason the MacPaint drawing area was 416 pixels wide. The drawing area is evenly divisible by 13 long words (13x32=416). This is exactly the number of registers that were available in the loop above for the MOVEM.L operation. <s>(It appears it could have used 14 registers, but I am guessing the extra 32 pixels would have made the drawing area more cramped by reducing the gray whitespace)</s> **UPDATE: several readers [helpfully pointed out](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=6982253) that only 13 registers were truly available. The other was reserved for the stack pointer (and the other two utilized as mentioned above). I remember "knowing" that only 13 were available back then when I discovered this, but when I wrote this article the fog of time had erased the true reason.**

It was fascinating to me that this particular M68k operation drove the visual design of the original, iconic, MacPaint application.

Of course one can critique it now and point out well what happens when you add color. And when you have a resizable window? But remember, this was the age of the Mac 128k, running on a 68k at 8Mhz. The ROM itself was just 64k and all of the core graphics (Quickdraw) was squeezed into 24k. This was an algorithm born of necessity. Without this optimization the original MacPaint would have been sluggish in many of its operations (the ScrnToBuf and the BufToScreen are foundational to MacPaint).

UPDATE: There are some good conversations about this article on [hacker news](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=6982253) and [reddit](http://i.reddit.com/r/programming/comments/1tzgyd/why_macpaints_window_size_was_416_pixels/). And if you liked this article, check out [A Great Old Timey Game Programming Hack](http://blog.moertel.com/posts/2013-12-14-great-old-timey-game-programming-hack.html) others pointed me to. A fascinating read.

posts.title: Cloud Experiences Need Maturing
posts.markdown:
Like most of you, I appreciative of the cloud and what it means to have an enormous amount of space that can follow you anywhere. However, I don't think that we have nailed the experience yet. A few cases in point seem to illustrate this. ## Google Drive vs Google Docs Google Drive started as Google Docs. Google Docs was all internet based documents. Google Drive (inspired by dropbox) syncs up a local drive with your Google Docs account if you choose to install it. Of course you don't have to install Google Drive on your computer. But even so Google redirects http://docs.google.com to http://drive.google.com and calls the product Google Drive. It takes the cloud model and maps a disk drive model on top of it. ![Screenshot of drive.google.com]() One place this disparity shows up is with documents shared with you in which you are an equal owner of the doc. It's usually a work document that whoever was quickest on the keyboard created first, and shared with the rest of the team. The author sees this document listed under their "My Drive" section. ![My Drive section]() But the other "authors" do not see it under "My Drive". Instead they see it under "Shared with Me". The problem is aggravated when you have a lot of files listed (but not organized) under "My Drive". When you come to drive.google.com you see a long list of files and start looking for the file (you don't necessarily remember whether you created it or someone shared it with you). For the longest time I thought this main list was "All my Files". But in fact there is no view that shows all your files at once. I am not really sure what the best solution is for this. It is a classic problem of exposing too much of the implementation model to the user and not understanding the user's mental model. While being able to filter by files I started vs files that were shared with me is useful, I am not sure it is the way most users think about their files. Especially ones that you have equal rights on. It was actually only after I decided to clean up "My Drive" area and get all the files into a few folders that I began to understand this problem. Interestingly when I start up drive.google.com it looks really sparse. It looks like I am missing something. In fact I was looking for a file the other day and looked in all "my folders" and couldn't find it. That is when I remembered that "Shared with Me" is a completely different set of files. None of them by default are in "My Drive". Unless of course you take the extra step of adding them to your "My Drive" section. Then they become part of your drive. And if you have Google Drive for your Mac or PC it also puts them on your local file system. Based on my experience and the feedback I have heard on twitter, I am not alone is struggling to find a document that got shared with you a few weeks ago. Here is @ThinkPhysics algorithm for finding documents.

@billwscott I have a workflow for that: 1. Click starred 2. Puzzle out loud, Huh, I cant believe I never starred that doc. 3. Search

— Matt Anthes-Washburn (@ThinkPhysics) January 4, 2014
